title: Learning-1
summary:
(170 words):**
Don Glendenning defines learning, teaching, and education with clarity and precision. He argues all PEI residents are potential learners who seek measurable change in knowledge, skills, attitudes, or values. Learners bring three elements to education: inherent physical/mental/emotional conditions; prior experiences from varied sources; and personal aspirations. Don defines learning as changing what one knows, feels, believes, and can do; teaching as arranging experiences enabling such change; and education as resulting from meaningful experiences. He notes that being "well-educated" means handling everyday life issues competently. Critically, Don rejects the conflation of school attendance with education—the World Bank warns this is problematic. He observes PEI educators lack shared definitions, potentially reflecting mission uncertainty, struggles with contemporary changes, and unclear educational services. He recommends reviewing common terminology, adopting shared definitions, implementing low-key systemic changes, ensuring conceptual clarity, and reconsidering educational goals and lifelong learning integration.

title: What standards
summary: Don critiques the current grading system and proposes improvements to competency-based occupational standards. He questions what letter grades actually communicate about student capability and advocates for standards that measure individual performance against real-world occupational criteria. He emphasizes that standards should focus on "how well one does it" not just "what one can do," establish multiple performance levels rather than artificial divisions, and incorporate professional judgment rather than seeking mechanical sorting. Don argues standards are separate from training and should be based on actual employment performance criteria like dependability, work quality, and team collaboration rather than credential possession.

summary: A revised version of the "Work" essay, presenting similar themes with enhanced clarity. Don emphasizes that while parents still believe schools should prepare students for work, educators have moved away from this objective. He notes the disconnect between school policy documentation and actual employment preparation, uses the term "weasel words" like "career exploration" and "job shadowing" to describe inadequate substitutes for genuine work readiness training. summary: This proposal establishes "Better Writing," a national not-for-profit organization to improve writing for all citizens. Glendenning argues that education is foundational to individual and community futures, with reading and writing as complementary key competencies. Better Writing would be governed by volunteer directors with education expertise but without current positions in the field, ensuring unaligned, transparent, evidence-based governance. The organization would provide volunteers, advocate for writing improvement, undertake research, produce educational materials, organize conferences and seminars, facilitate discussion groups, and foster cooperation among interested parties.
